newsitem.title: USA: Carriers not keen to raise transpac rates - NCA.
newsitem.headline: Carriers not keen to raise transpac rates - NCA.

text.p: There will be no repeat of the Feb 1 air freight rate increases of the previous two years on U.S.-Asia corridors as carriers pursue a wait-and-see course, an official of Nippon Cargo Airlines said on Monday
No airline has announced a Feb one increase, NCA has no plans to move on March one either "and after that I can't say", said Pete Diefenbach, manager of U.S. marketing for the
U.S.-Japan freight rates rose on Feb 1 of both 1995 and 1996, and many U.S.-Asia rates rose in lockstep.
"I would expect that everybody wants to see how the first quarter of '97 shakes out" before moving on rates, Diefenbach told Reuters.
NCA imposed a fuel surcharge of $0.10/kilo from the U.S. on Dec 9.
Freight forwarders now want at least two months' notice of any increase, he added.
Besides concerns about a slower rate of growth in 1997, carriers are watching the impact of recent or pending capacity additions in the U.S.-Japan and US-Asia markets.

These include new freighter services inaugurated last year by operators like UPS and Federal Express. Also, Chicago-based United Airlines has scheduled the launch of its long-awaited transpacific freighter service for March.
Additionally, new passenger flights between the U.S. and the Asian mainland on a number of carriers is bringing additional capacity into play as well, said Diefenbach.
